div.l: Oure Corn̄ is stolen̄ men̄ wil us folis calle
Bothe the wardein and oure felawes all
And nameli the mylner welaway
Thus playneth Iohn as he goth bi the way
Toward the mylne and bayard in his hand
Þe mylner sittyng bi the fire he fand
For it was night and ferre might þei nouȝt
But for the loue of god thei him besought
Of harborou and of ease as for their͗e peny
The mylner ansuerd agein if ther͗e be eny
Such as it is yit shul ye haue your͗e part
Myn̄ hous is streit but ye han̄ lerned art
Ye can̄ by Argumentꝭis makea Place
A myle brood of twenti foot of space
Lat se now if this place may suffice
Or make more rome wᵗith speche as is yoıı̄ur gise
Now Symond seid this Iohn be seint cutberd
Ay is thou meri and that is feir ansuerd
I haue herd sey þat men̄ shul take one of ij þingꝭis
Sike as he findis or take sike as he bringꝭis
But speciali I pray thee myn̄ host dere
Gete us sum̄ mete and drink ⁊and make chere
And we wille paye truly atte the fulle
With empti handis men mai not haukꝭis tulle
Lo here oure siluer redy forto Spende
The mylner to the toun̄ his dought̉er send
For ale and brede and rostid hem a goos
And bound her hors he shuld no mor͗e go loos
And in his ovn̄ chambir he made a bedde
With shetis and wᵗith chalons feir͗e y spredde
Not from his ovn̄ bedde ten̄ foot or tuelue
His doughtir had a bedde alle by hirselue
Right in the same chambir by and by
It might be no bette and cause why
Þer nas no romer herborou in that place
Thei soupid and speken of Solace
And drank euer͗e strong ale at the bes
